reasoning: The critique targets speculative empirical/technological premises (rapid expansion, effective capture of most accessible resources, huge digital populations) that the position uses heavily in its “linear-in-resources/astronomical scale” and ‘tiny fraction of bads matters’ illustrations. If those premises fail, some of the paper’s most quantitative fussiness arguments weaken, so centrality is moderate. However, the core ‘no easy eutopia’ thesis also rests on broadly moral/philosophical claims about value fragility across many dimensions and on the difficulty of finding genuinely easygoing value functions; those survive even with slower expansion or smaller scale, so the attack is not fully central. Strength is moderate-low because the critique mostly points to uncertainty and asks for sensitivity analysis rather than showing the relevant empirical assumptions are false or that the conclusions are robustly unchanged; it undercuts confidence/action-guidance more than it refutes. The critique is largely correct that these claims are highly uncertain and confidence could be overstated, though it somewhat overstates by suggesting the reasoning becomes largely irrelevant rather than partially weakened. It is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Speculative technological assumptions need sensitivity analysis to support conclusions
